item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Steelhead salmon passage counts at Bonneville Dam
item.description:
Introduction

This analysis looks at Steelhead salmon passage across the Bonneville Dam in Oregon from 1940 - 2019. The primary data collection is done byt the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. The data includes counts of Steelhead Salmon recorded daily. There were days that did not include any salmon recordings and these data were removed from the analysis. Included in this analysis are a graph of daily recordings, a comparison of how seasonal recordings have changed over the years, and a graph of annual counts.

Reference: Columbia River DART, Columbia Basin Research, University of Washington. (2019). Adult Passage Graphics & Text. Available from http://www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_graph_text

Bonneville Dam spillway. Photo curtesy of the Bonneville Dam Wikipedia page, visitor7.

Visualing exploring the data

# -----------------
# Install libraries
# ------------------

library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(here)
library(lubridate)
library(paletteer)
library(tsibble)

# ----------------
# Read in csv
# ---------------

steelhead <- read_csv("cbr_fish_passage_bonneville_allyrs_steelhead.csv") %>% 
  clean_names()

# Note on data classes: year is number & mm_dd is character
# Also mm_dd is mislabeled, it is actually dd_mm
# ---------------
# Correct dates
# ---------------

steelhead_dates <- steelhead %>% 
  # combine date columns using str_c
  mutate(yr_day_mo = str_c(year, mm_dd, sep = "-")) %>% 
  # convert to date format using parse_date_time
  mutate(yr_mo_day = lubridate::parse_date_time(yr_day_mo, "ydm")) %>% 
  # add month, day, & year columns and remove unneccesary date columns
  select(-mm_dd, -year, -yr_day_mo) %>% 
  mutate(month = month(yr_mo_day, label = TRUE)) %>% 
  mutate(day = day(yr_mo_day)) %>% 
  mutate(year = year(yr_mo_day))
# ------------
# Timeseries plot
# ------------

steel_timeseries <- steelhead_dates %>% 
  # remove all observations with NA for date or value
  # note, value is the count of salmon that were recorded passing the damn
  drop_na(yr_mo_day, value)

steel_gg <- ggplot(data = steel_timeseries,
                   aes(x = yr_mo_day,
                       y = value)) +
  geom_line() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Daily Dates",
       y = "Count of Steelhead Salmon",
       title = "Counts of Steelhead Salmon Passing Bonneville Dam 
       (Daily records from 1940-2018)") +
  # center the title
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) 

steel_gg

  • There was a large spike in steelhead salmon counts in August 2009.
# -------------
# Season plot
# -------------

steel_season <- steel_timeseries %>% 
  # mutate(decade = round_date(year, unit = )) %>% 
  group_by(year, month) %>% 
  summarize(average_count = mean(value))

steel_season_gg <- ggplot(data = steel_season,
                          aes(x = month,
                              y = average_count,
                              group = year)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = year)) +
  scale_color_paletteer_c("grDevices::SunsetDark") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Month",
       y = "Average count of Steelhead Salmon",
       title = "Steelhead Salmon Passing Bonneville Dam
       Average daily counts by month (1940-2019)") +
  # center the title
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) 

steel_season_gg

  • The largest amount of steelhead salmon pass through the Bonneville Dam in the summer months.
  • The number of total salmon observed has increased overtime.
# ------------
# Annual steelhead passage counts
# ------------

steel_annual <- steel_timeseries %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  summarize(total_count = sum(value))

steel_annual_gg <- ggplot(data = steel_annual,
                          aes(x = year,
                              y = total_count)) +
  geom_line() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Year",
       y = "Annual count of Steelhead Salmon",
       title = "Counts of Steelhead Salmon Passing Bonneville Dam 
       (Annual totals from 1940-2019)") +
  # center the title
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) 

steel_annual_gg

  • Steelhead Salmon counts increased dramatically starting in 1980 with peaks in 2001 and 2009
  • There has been an equally drastic drop in counts in the past decade

item.title: Analysis of Pacific Giant Salamanders in Mack Creek, OR
item.description:
Introduction

Nestled alongside Oregon’s McKenzie River lies Mack Creek, a forest-dense aquatic area that provides habitat for the Pacific Giant Salamander. The density of forest alongside Mack Creek varies greatly between different forest sections due to historic forest clear-cutting. It is not fully understood whether the clear-cutting of forest has had a significant impact on the Pacific Giant Salamander population in Mack Creek. Fortunately, for the purposes of this report, the Pacific Giant Salamander population along Mack Creek has been monitored in both a clear-cut forest section and a 500-year-old, old-growth forest section since 1993 (Gregory S. V. 2016). Data from this monitoring of Pacific Giant Salamanders includes the specific location of individual observations, overall counts, and individual weights (Gregory S. V. 2016). Here, we analyze this data to provide insight into the the effect that forest clear-cutting has on Pacific Giant Salamander populations in Mack Creek.

Mack Creek Location. Dana Warren.

Pacific Giant Salamander. Photo by Karl H. Switak

Data and Methods

Annually collected data on the Pacific giant salamanders from 1993 to 2017 in the old growth section and the previously clear-cut section of the Andrews Experimental Forest was used for the analysis. Among these two groups, counts, weights, and location of salamanders within the Mack Creek channel (pool, cascade, or side-channel) were analyzed using a significance level of 0.05. For more information on collection methods and variables, see metadata. A chi-squared test was used to determine if there is a significant effect of forest condition (old growth vs clear cut) on where in the channel Pacific Giant Salamander’s are found (Cascades, Side-Channel, and Pool). A two-sample t-test was used to compare the weights of Pacific Giant Salamanders between the two forest sections. Lastly, a one-way ANOVA test, along with Tukey’s HSD and Cohen’s D for post-hoc testing was conducted to compare mean weights across channel locations.

Results

Part A: Visual Comparison of Salamander Counts

Figure 1: Counts of Pacific Giant Salamander’s compared between clear-cut forest section and old-growth forest section between 1993 and 2017.

Trends in Giant Pacific Salamander counts were compared between clear-cut and old-growth forest sections between 1993 and 2017 (Figure 1). Noticeably, there is little visual difference in the fluctuation of salamander counts in old-growth and clear-cut forest sections. Despite little difference in the fluctuation of salamander counts, on average, salamander counts in old-growth forest sections were greater until 2014. Populations of Giant Pacific Salamanders in both the clear-cut and old-growth forest sections experienced significant decline in populations between 2013 and 2015.

Results B: 2017 Salamander Counts by Channel Classification

Table 1: 2017 Salamander counts by channel classification (pool, cascades, and side-channel) in old-growth and clear-cut sections of Mack Creek. Proportions provide insight into the relationship that exists between forest section and the channel section where Pacific Giant Salamanders were observed.
Section Cascades Pool Side Channel
Clear Cut 247 (67.1%) 31 (8.4%) 90 (24.5%)
Old Growth 201 (62.8%) 45 (14.1%) 74 (23.1%)

Results C: Analysis of Salamander Counts by Channel Classification

A chi-squared test of independence was conducted to analyze whether there is a significant effect of forest condition on the channel classification where Pacific Giant Salamanders were observed. The analysis shows that, at a 95% confidence level, there is not a significant effect of forest section on where Pacific Giant Salamanders were observed (p-value: 0.0626). Despite unequal distribution of salamander counts across forest sections (as seen in Table 1), there is not a statistically significant relationship that exists between forest section and channel classification at the 95% confidence level.

Results D: Pacific Giant Salamander Weights by Section

Figure 2: Comparison of weights of Pacific Giant Salamanders observed in clear-cut forest section and old-growth forest section. Mean weight is displayed as black dot with error bars that display one standard deviation from mean. Mean weight of Pacific Giant Salamanders in clear-cut forest sections = 7.78g, and old-growth forest section = 6.58g.

A Welch’s two sample t-test was conducted to analyze whether there is a significant difference in mean weight of Pacific Giant Salamanders in clear-cut and old-growth forest sections. Test results show that, at a 95% confidence level, there is not a significant difference in the mean weight of Pacific Giant Salamanders between the two forest sections (p-value: 0.096). These results reinforce findings in Results A, Results B, and Results C, that indicate that there is no significant effect of forest section on Pacific Giant Salamander populations in Mack Creek.

Results E: Means Comparison of Salamander Weight by Channel Classification

Figure 3: Comparison of weights of Pacific Giant Salamanders observed in Cascades, Pools, or Side Channels.

 

Figure 4: QQ plot to explore normalcy of data spread for weights of Pacific Giant Salamanders observed in different channel classifications (Cascades, Pool, Side-Channel). Actual values of observations were plotted with theoretical normal values and yielded slightly abnormal results.

Levene’s Test for Equal Variance

  • Levene’s Test Result: With a p-value of 0.093, this is not significant and we retain the null hypothesis of equal variances.

One-way ANOVA & Post-Hoc Testing:

  • ANOVA Result: Mean salamander weight (g) differed significantly between the three channel classifications (pool, cascade, side-channel) based on a one-way ANOVA test (F(2, 684) = 4.22, p-value = 0.015).
  • Tukey’s HSD Result: Pairwise testing reveals that mean weights of Pool salamanders differ significantly from Side Channel salamanders (p-value = 0.017), however, means of other pairwise combinations do not differ significantly. Pool salamanders and Cascade salamanders: (p-value = 0.286). Side channel salamanders and Cascade salamanders: (p-value = 0.084)
  • Effect size: Even though a significant difference in means is found between salamanders sampled in pools vs. side-channels, the effect size is small as tested with Cohen’s d: (d estimate = 0.35)

Analysis of Results

  • An Anova test was conducted to compare mean weights of salamanders across channel classifications, regardless of forest section. The results show that at the 95% confidence level, mean salamander weight was only significantly different between salamanders in side channels vs those in pools. While significantly different, the effect size is small, thus leading a conclusion that there is not considerable difference in Pacific Giant Salamander weight across channel classifications.
  • Prior to conducting the ANOVA, a QQ plot was created to evaluate normalcy of the weight distributions. The QQ plot revealed that the distributions of weights within each channel type is slightly abnormal. While this raises slight concern for the effectiveness of an ANOVA, it is widely accepted that an ANOVA is robust to violation of the normality assumption. Coupled with a Levene’s test that indicates non-significant difference in variance, the results of the ANOVA test are still valuable. Median weights should be compared for further analysis.

Summary

  • Pacific Giant Salamander counts have fluctuated greatly in Mack Creek from 1993 to 2018. These fluctuations have largely been the same in the previously clear cut section of the forest as in the old growth section of forest (Figure 1).
  • In 2017, mean weight of Pacfic Giant Salamanders sampled in clear-cut forests were 1.2 grams larger (~18% larger) than those sampled in old growth forest sections.(Figure 2)
  • Despite differences in actual data, statistical tests show inconclusive evidence that any strong relationships exist at the 95% confidence level between 1) forest section and where the Pacific Giant Salamander are found, 2) weights of the salamanders across forest sections, and 3) weights of the salamanders across channel classifications. (Results B, C, D, & E)

References

Gregory S. V. 2016. Aquatic Vertebrate Population Study in Mack Creek, Andrews Experimental Forest, 1987 to present. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/5de64af9c11579266ef20da2ff32f702. Dataset accessed 12/01/2019

item.title: Effect of Marine Protected Area Designation on Spiny Lobster Populations
item.description:
Introduction

In 2012, the California Fish and Game Network of Marine Protected Areas (MPA) established two MPAs along the Santa Barbara coastline, one in Isla Vista and another in Naples (Reed 2019). Like much of the Santa Barbara coastline, Isla Vista and Naples are home to the spiny lobster. The spiny lobster serves as an important predator in kelp forests off the California coastline (Reed 2019). Since 2012, the Santa Barbara Coastal Long-Term Ecological Research program (SBC LTER) has collected annual data on the size and abundance of spiny lobsters from five sites along the Santa Barbara coastline (Reed 2019). The SBC LTER data is collected from the two MPA sites mentioned above and three non-MPA sites along the Santa Barbara coastline, Mohawk, Arroyo Quemado, and Carpinteria. A comparison of the size and abundance of spiny lobsters between these five sites provides useful insight into the impact that MPAs have spiny lobster populations. This report uses the SBC LTER data to analyze the effect that MPAs have had on the size and abundance of spiny lobsters along the Santa Barbara coastline between 2012 and 2018.

California Spiny Lobsters offshore of Anacapa Island. Photo by Ed Bierman

Data and Methods

Data used for this study includes: 1) spiny lobster counts within designated transects at each site measured annually in late summer before the fishing season, and 2) the visually estimated sizes of these lobsters. Visualizations and statistics were used to identify interesting trends of these variables. Two sided T-tests were conducted to measure the significance of differences in mean lobster sizes and counts between Marine Protected Areas and non-Marine Protected Areas and also between 2012 and 2018 for each of those two groups. These tests were conducted at a 5% signficance level. Software used for this analysis includes R-Studio Version 1.2.1335 and GitHub.

Results

A. Spiny Lobster Counts

Figure 1: Figure 1: Annual change in spiny lobster population between the five Santa Barbara coastline data collection sites (Isla Vista, Naples, Carpinteria, Mohawk, and Arroyo Quemado) from 2012 to 2018. MPA sites are delineated with red lines and non-MPA sites are delineated with blue lines.

Interesting trends:
  • Isla Vista has seen the largest increase in spiny lobster count by far among the five locations analyzed
  • Populations increased by well over 100% in Isla Vista and Carpenteria from 2016 - 2017
  • Marine Protected Areas showed gradual increase in lobster counts following their protection status in January, 2012 but this did not persist for Naples
  • Carpinteria (Non-MPA) and Isla Vista (MPA) were on similar trajectories between 2016 and 2017. Carpentiria, which is a non-MPA saw a major decline between 2017 and 2018, whereas Isla Vista, which is an MPA, did not.

B. Size Distribution Comparison

Figure 2: Figure 2: Spread of lobster sizes for each of the five Santa Barbara coastline sites for the years 2012 and 2018. Red colors are for Marine Protected Area sites while blue colors are for non-Marine Protected Area Sites. Change in median size from 2012-2018 for MPA was +13.5 mm while change in median size for non-MPA was -2 mm. Data: Santa Barbara Coastal Long-Term Ecological Research program

Interesting trends:
  • Marine Protected Areas (Naples and Isla Vista) saw very clear increases in median sizes from 2012 to 2018
  • The spread of sizes noticibly decreased for Naples, Mohawk, and Carpenteria from 2012 - 2018, while it did not change at Arroyo Quemado and it increased at Isla Vista.

C. Comparison of Mean Lobster Sizes

MPA vs. non-MPA in 2012 (Question 1):
  • Mean lobster size differed significantly between MPA and non-MPA sites in 2012 (t(42.09) = -3.25, p = 2.26e-03.
  • Mean for MPA in 2012 = 67.375 \(\pm\) 12.1542506
  • Mean for non-MPA in 2012 = 74.9246231 \(\pm\) 12.4141231
  • Actual difference in mean size: -7.55 mm
  • Confidence Interval: 95%
  • Effect Size using Cohen’s D: -0.61
MPA vs. non-MPA in 2018 (Question 2):
  • Mean lobster size differed significantly between MPA and non-MPA sites in 2018 (t(1239.51) = 7.31, p = 4.88e-13.
  • Mean for MPA in 2018 = 77.5667203 \(\pm\) 11.7034098
  • Mean for non-MPA in 2018 = 73.6199643 \(\pm\) 10.0943775
  • Actual difference in mean size: 3.95 mm
  • Confidence Interval: 95%
  • Effect Size using Cohen’s D: 0.35
2012 vs. 2018 for MPAs only (Question 3):
  • Mean lobster size differed significantly between 2018 and 2012 for MPA sites (t(32.5) = -4.69, p = 4.76e-05.
  • Actual difference in mean size: 10.19 mm
  • % change from 2012 to 2018: +15%
  • Confidence Interval: 95%
  • Effect Size using Cohen’s D: 0.87
2012 vs. 2018 for non-MPAs only (Question 4):
  • Mean lobster size did not differ significantly between 2018 and 2012 for non-MPA sites (t(296.01) = 1.33, p = 0.1831.
  • Actual difference in mean size: -1.3 mm
  • % change from 2012 to 2018: -2%
  • Confidence Interval: 95%
  • Effect Size using Cohen’s D: -0.12

Summary

  • From 2012 to 2018, spiny lobster counts in MPA sites increased at a greater rate than spiny lobster counts in non-MPA sites (Figure 1).
  • From 2012 and 2018, the mean size of spiny lobsters increased by 15% for MPA sites whereas it decreased by 2% for non-MPA sites.
  • Between 2012 and 2018, mean spiny lobster sizes in the MPA sites went from being 7.55mm smaller than spiny lobsters in non-MPAs to being 3.95mm larger.

References

Reed D. 2019. SBC LTER: Reef: Abundance, size and fishing effort for California Spiny Lobster (Panulirus interruptus), ongoing since 2012. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/a593a675d644fdefb736750b291579a0. Dataset accessed 11/15/2019.

item.title: Writing technical content in Academic
item.description:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.

Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.

On this page, you’ll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.

Examples

Code

Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.toml file.

```python
import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()
```

renders as

import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()

Math

Academic supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.toml file.

To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with $...$ or $$...$$, respectively.

Example math block:

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ 
\left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T 
\left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}
{\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$

renders as

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left |\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right |^2}$$

Example inline math $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$ renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.

Example multi-line math using the \\ math linebreak:

$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$

renders as

$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$

Diagrams

Academic supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.

An example flowchart:

```mermaid
graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]
```

renders as

graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]

An example sequence diagram:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!
```

renders as

sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!

An example Gantt diagram:

```mermaid
gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d
```

renders as

gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d

An example class diagram:

```mermaid
classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
<<interface>> Class01
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
class Class10 {
  <<service>>
  int id
  size()
}
```

renders as

classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
<<interface>> Class01
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
class Class10 {
  <<service>>
  int id
  size()
}

An example state diagram:

```mermaid
stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]
```

renders as

stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]

Todo lists

You can even write your todo lists in Academic too:

- [x] Write math example
- [x] Write diagram example
- [ ] Do something else

renders as

  • Write math example
  • Write diagram example
  • Do something else

Tables

Represent your data in tables:

| First Header  | Second Header |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |

renders as

First Header Second Header
Content Cell Content Cell
Content Cell Content Cell

Asides

Academic supports a shortcode for asides, also referred to as notices, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% alert note %}} ... {{% /alert %}}, it will render as an aside.

{{% alert note %}}
A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.
{{% /alert %}}

renders as

A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.

Icons

Academic enables you to use a wide range of icons from Font Awesome and Academicons in addition to emojis.

Here are some examples using the icon shortcode to render icons:

{{< icon name="terminal" pack="fas" >}} Terminal  
{{< icon name="python" pack="fab" >}} Python  
{{< icon name="r-project" pack="fab" >}} R

renders as

Terminal
Python
R

item.title: Display Jupyter Notebooks with Academic
item.description:
from IPython.core.display import Image
Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png')


print("Welcome to Academic!")

Welcome to Academic!

Install Python and JupyterLab

Install Anaconda which includes Python 3 and JupyterLab.

Alternatively, install JupyterLab with pip3 install jupyterlab.

Create or upload a Jupyter notebook

Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:

mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
jupyter lab index.ipynb

The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.

Edit your post metadata

The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata ( front matter).

In Jupter, choose Markdown as the type of the first cell and wrap your Academic metadata in three dashes, indicating that it is YAML front matter:

---
title: My post's title
date: 2019-09-01

# Put any other Academic metadata here...
---

Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.

To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post’s folder.

For other tips, such as using math, see the guide on writing content with Academic.

Convert notebook to Markdown

jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=.

Example

This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description:
R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)
##      speed           dist       
##  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
##  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
##  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
##  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
##  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
##  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
fit
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)        speed  
##     -17.579        3.932

Including Plots

You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)
